sub_topic: Calculation of magnetic field due to a current-carrying helix
message_1: A physics student needs to calculate the magnetic field generated by a helical coil carrying a current of 5 A, with a radius of 10 cm and a pitch of 8 cm, at a distance of 15 cm from its center along the central axis of the coil.
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic field generated by a helical coil, we can use the Biot-Savart law. However, for a helical coil, the calculation can be quite complex. Instead, we can use an approximation formula for the magnetic field along the central axis of a solenoid, which is a closely wound helical coil. The formula is:

B = (μ₀ * n * I) / (1 + (z / R)²)^(3/2)

where B is the magnetic field, μ₀ is the permeability of free space (4π x 10^(-7) Tm/A), n is the number of turns per unit length, I is the current, z is the distance from the center of the coil along the central axis, and R is the radius of the coil.

First, we need to find the number of turns per unit length (n). We can do this by dividing the number of turns in one pitch by the pitch length:

n = 1 / (pitch length)

In this case, the pitch is 8 cm, so:

n = 1 / 0.08 m = 12.5 turns/m

Now we can plug in the values into the formula:

B = (4π x 10^(-7) Tm/A * 12.5 turns/m * 5 A) / (1 + (0.15 m / 0.1 m)²)^(3/2)

B ≈ (7.85 x 10^(-6) T) / (1 + 2.25)^(3/2)

B ≈ (7.85 x 10^(-6) T) / (3.25)^(3/2)

B ≈ (7.85 x 10^(-6) T) / 5.69

B ≈ 1.38 x 10^(-6) T

So, the magnetic field generated by the helical coil at a distance of 15 cm from its center along the central axis is approximately 1.38 x 10^(-6) T.
